title.narrative: OUTPUT 2.1: KIR - Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH)

description.narrative: Output 2.1 By 2017, communities, schools and health centers use improved water and sanitation facilities with a focus on outer islands, rural and peri-urban villages in Kiribati, which contributes to Hygiene, Sanitation, Wash And Emergencies, Wash In Schools And Ecd Centres, Wash â€“ General, Water, Water Supply. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: H&S Programme Component Results (PCR) 2: Children and families benefit from equitable and sustainable access to safe drinking water, improved sanitation and hygiene within communities that are increasingly resilient to the impact of climate change and natural disasters.

MINISTRY OF HEALTH SAMOA FORMER NHS OF SAMOA

mailing-address.narrative: 3rd & 5th Floors FDB Building 360 Victoria Parade Suva

sector.narrative: Management and Operations support at CO
Sanitation - eliminating open defecation in peri-urban and urban communities
Sanitation - improving services in rural communities (except household water treatment and storage, moving up the ladder and strengthening sustainability)
Sanitation and hygiene - eliminating open defecation in rural communities
Sanitation and hygiene - institutions (schools, health care facilities, ECD centres) including menstrual hygiene management
WASH - Enabling environment (policies/strategies, coordination, regulation, financing, planning-monitoring-review, sector capacity development and professionalization)
Water - climate resilience and environmental sustainability
Water supply - rural communities service delivery

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 2.1 By 2017, communities, schools and health centers use improved water and sanitation facilities with a focus on outerislands, rural and peri-urban villages in Kiribati

description.narrative: A Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) in Schools programme implemented by the Kiribati Ministry of Education allowed 4,562 students in 32 schools on four outer islands to use improved WASH facilities and the Ministry of Health and Medical Services completed a first-ever assessment of WASH facilities in 22 clinics. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:24/11/2017

title.narrative: (NOT VALID after Dec 31 2017) ) Schools at which WASH facilities have been installed in the reporting year only, with UNICEF direct support
(NOT VALID after Dec 31 2017) ) Communities triggered through CATS/CLTS programmes in the reporting year only as a result of UNICEF direct support

actual.value: 2017:The CLTS target was up to 2016 with no target for 2017. UNICEF exceeded the 2016 target and triggered more than 103 communities.

title.narrative: Number of project communities achieving Open Defecation Free Status
% of the target population using an improved sanitation facility
% of the target population using an improved drinking water source
(NOT VALID after Dec 31 2017) ) Community-based hand-washing behaviour change Communication programme implemented on a national scale

actual.value: 2017:Kiribati has a UNICEF developed communication for development strategy not yet endorsed by the Ministry. However, to date, it has rolled out videos and dramas across 5 of the major outer islands

title.narrative: National standards for WASH in schools with a disability component available

actual.value: 2017:National Minimum Standard for WASH but there is a National Infrastructure Standard which and Inclusive Education Policy which has disability component

title.narrative: National strategy to eliminate open defecation available

actual.value: 2017:While the government of Kiribati has not developed a strategy to eliminate open defecation, UNICEF has supported the development of WASH Safety Planning that provides a checklist to assess risks of open defecation and a menu of options for suitable toilets.
